member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Algorithms.PeriodicResolverParameters.MaximumWaitDelay
member.summary: Maximum allowed wait time before a resolution attempt. In milliseconds.

remarks.para: is kind of maximum allowed age of the resolution result. If a retrial has been scheduled for an earlier time, its resolution result will be used. Otherwise, a new resolution is scheduled, using the counted from the last resolution time.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Collections.ElasticVector
member.summary: A one-dimensional array that expands its bounds elastically.

remarks.para: The vector can grow automatically with certain operations. It does not shrink by itself. The growing constitutes of lowering the lower bound or increasing the upper bound as necessary for the operation. The absolute element indexes remain unchanged, even when the lower bound changes.

Besides its elasticity, this class is also designed to be conveniently usable for working around limitations of some COM tools and languages that cannot handle construction or deconstruction of proper arrays for method arguments and return values.

For passing an array into a COM method, the developer can create , fill it with elements, and then use its method to obtain the underlying array object, and pass it to the COM method. Conversely, the developer can create , call its method with the method return value, and then use methods such as to retrieve the elements.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Collections.ElasticVector.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the elastic vector that is empty.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Collections.ElasticVector.#ctor(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the elastic vector with specified lower bound and length.

member.summary: Initialized a new instance of the elastic vector, with bounds and elements copied from a given other elastic vector.
member.param: Elastic vector to be copied from.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the elastic vector that uses the specified underlying array object.
member.param: The array object to be used by the elastic vector.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Collections.ElasticVector.LowerBound
member.summary: Gets the index of the first element in the elastic vector.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Collections.ElasticVector.UpperBound
member.summary: Gets the index of the last element in the elastic vector.

remarks.para: The upper dimension is -1 if the elastic vector is empty.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Collections.ElasticVector.AddRange(System.Collections.IEnumerable)
member.summary: Adds the elements of the specified sequence to the end of the elastic vector.
member.param: The sequence whose elements should be added to the end of the elastic vector. The sequence itself cannot be null, but it can contain elements that are null.

remarks.para: This method can be used in certain COM tools (such as Xojo) to convert keyed collections (whose elements cannot otherwise be enumerated in such tools) to an elastic vector, from which all the elements can then be extracted by index.

Note that with an empty elastic vector, and an actual argument that is an array, the method still differs from the method in that the method takes over the (lower and upper) dimensions of the input array into the elastic vector, while the method (on an empty elastic vector) always results in an elastic vector with zero .

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Collections.ElasticVector.Assign(System.Object[])
member.summary: Assigns the underlying array object of the elastic vector.
member.param: The array object to be used by the elastic vector.

remarks.para: The old content of the elastic vector is lost.

member.summary: Gets the element at the specified index.
member.param: The index of the element to get.
member.returns: The element with the specified index.

remarks.para: The elasticity dot not apply in this method. The index must fall into the current bounds of the elastic vector.

member.summary: Changes the lower and upper bounds of the elastic vector.
member.param: The new lower bound of the elastic vector.
The new upper bound of the elastic vector.

member.summary: Removes the first occurrence of a specific object from the elastic vector.
member.param: The object to remove form the elastic vector.
member.returns: true if was found in and successfully removed from the elastic vector; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Changes the number of elements of an elastic vector to the specified new size.
member.param: The new size of the elastic vector.

remarks.para: As opposed to , the elastic vector does not have to be zero-based

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Collections.ThreadSafe.Resource1.ThreadSafeQueue_ThreadSafeQueue_The_boundedCapacity_is_not_a_positive_value_
member.summary: Looks up a localized string similar to The boundedCapacity is not a positive value..

remarks.para: As opposed to ConcurrentQueue<T>, this class is available in pre-.NET 4, and it also supports a limit on the number of elements. Note that BoundedCollection<T> can also be used for similar purposes, but again it's only available in .NET 4+.
As opposed to , this class has a bounded capacity, and offers "TryXXXX" members that do not throw exceptions unnecessarily.

member.summary: Provides helper methods for interoperability with the COM technology.

member.summary: An instance of the interop helper object.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComInterop.InteropHelper.AsObject(System.Object)
member.summary: Casts the input argument to an .
member.param: The object to be cast.
member.returns: Returns the input argument, cast to an .

remarks.para: This method is useful in some COM tools (such as PHP) that do not allow to navigate between COM interfaces of an object, or provide an "amalgamated" set of members from multiple interfaces, when a specific interface is returned by a property or method. This leads to a problem if you want to downcast the object you have to a derived type. By passing the object through this method, the consuming COM tool is forced to use late binding, allowing the intended members be accessed.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComInterop.VarType
member.summary: Data type specifications used in COM. Contains .NET equivalents of COM VARTYPE.

remarks.para: Certain bitwise operations, such as ORing the VT_ARRAY with the element type, are allowed. Windows has some limitations as to which combinations can be made. Also, different types are permissible in different contexts.
The enumeration contains similar members, but is not well suited for uses other than described there. Do not confuse the two.

member.summary: Gets or sets COM object's class identifier (CLSID).
member.remarks: A CLSID is a globally unique identifier that identifies an object. The object needs to register its CLSID with the system.

member.summary: The component categories implemented by the class.

member.summary: Determines whether this object is a null COM class registration.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComInterop.Database.ComClassRegistration.ObjectId
member.summary: Contains the object ID, i.e. ProgID, {CLSID}, or ProgID/{CLSID}.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComInterop.Database.ComClassRegistration.ProgId
member.summary: Gets or sets a string value indicating the programmatic identifier (ProgID) of the COM object.
member.remarks: ProgIDs present a human-readable version of the class identifier (CLSID) used to identify COM/ActiveX objects.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComInterop.Database.ComClassRegistration.TypeLibId
member.summary: The globally unique identifier (GUID) of the Type Library associated with a COM object.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComInterop.Database.ComClassRegistration.VersionIndependentProgId
member.summary: Gets or sets version-independent programmatic identifier of the COM object application.

remarks.para: The VersionIndependentProgID associates a ProgID with a CLSID.

The version-independent ProgID refers to the COM object's class and does not change from version to version, instead remaining constant across all versions. It refers to the currently installed version of the COM object's class. The version-independent ProgID corresponds to the name of the latest version of the COM object application.

remarks.para: If there are pages with Ids between 1 - 999, the page (Id 0) will not be used inside the object editor.
Pages with Ids of 10000 and more may be initially hidden from display, and shown by something like ">>> More" command from the user.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.ControlPageIds.Multi
member.summary: The Multi control page. Denotes a control with pages in Id range 0-999.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.ControlPageIds.ViewOrEdit
member.summary: The View or Edit control page (Id 0).

remarks.para: The title of the page is chosen depending on whether the control is read-only or read-write.
This is the default of .

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.ControlPageIds.Basic
member.summary: The Basic control page.

remarks.para: When present, it should be accompanied by some complementary page, such as .

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.ControlPageIds.Physical
member.summary: The Physical control page.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.ControlPageIds.Communication
member.summary: The Communication control page.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.ControlPageIds.Logical
member.summary: The Logical control page.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.ControlPageIds.Advanced
member.summary: The Advanced control page.

remarks.para: This page is intended to be used in conjunction with other pages in the range 1 - 999, but not with the page. This is different from the page, which is intended to be used together with page, in cases when the View/Edit page does contain complete information.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.ControlPageIds.Properties
member.summary: The Properties control page (Id 1000).

remarks.para: Contains a property grid.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.ControlPageIds.Expert
member.summary: The Expert control page.

remarks.para: This page is intended to be used together with page, in cases when the View/Edit page does contain complete information. This is different from the page, which is intended to be used in conjunction with other pages in the range 1 - 999, but not with the page.

member.summary: The Serialization control page.

member.summary: Named values of standard control page Ids.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.DataAnnotations.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: This namespace provides attribute classes that are used to define metadata for data controls.

remarks.para: Default value is 0, thus unless specified otherwise, all columns have refinement rank zero. Most user agents will, by default, show columns with refinement rank less than or equal to zero. All columns will therefore be shown for unannotated objects. The developer who wants his objects be displayed better will annotate less important columns with refinement rank 1 or higher, making them "disappear" by default, or in lower display refinement levels.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.LicensingManagement
member.summary: Provides way to manage licensing.

remarks.para: This class is not thread safe.
This class is not static, so that COM clients can also instantiate and use it.
This object is a semi-singleton, i.e. all instances of it share the same data.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.LicensingManagement.Instance
member.summary: An instance of the licensing management object.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.LicensingManagement.RegisterFile(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Registers a license located in a file.
member.param: Name of the licensing component for which the location of the license should be registered. Consult the documentation for the value that corresponds to your product.
ID of the license for whose location should be registered. Consult the documentation for the values to be used with your product.
The name of the file containing the license.
member.exception: A license file is already registered for and .

remarks.para: The same combination of and must not (and cannot) be registered more than once. An attempt to do so will result in an . Be careful not to put the registration code into Web request handlers (without further logic) which are called repeatedly.

The actual presence and validity of the license is not checked at the time when the location is registered. If you want an exception be thrown when the file does not exist or is not accessible, use the method.

exception.para: A null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) is passed to a method that does not accept it as a valid argument.
This is a usage error, i.e. it will never occur (the exception will not be thrown) in a correctly written program. Your code should not catch this exception.

member.exception: An invalid Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) was detected.

The name of the file containing the license.

This is a usage error, i.e. it will never occur (the exception will not be thrown) in a correctly written program. Your code should not catch this exception.

member.exception: An invalid Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) was detected.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.IValueControl
member.summary: A control that is associated with a value.

remarks.para: This is a generalized value control concept that is independent of the concrete UX framework, such as Windows Forms.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.IValueControl.IsNullable
member.summary: Determines whether the interactive user of the control can set the value to null.

remarks.para: The control's value can be null even in controls that are not nullable (their is false).
The default value of this property must be equal to the corresponding value.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.IValueControl.IsPolymorphic
member.summary: Determines whether the interactive user of the control can change the type of the value.

remarks.para: The default value of this property must be equal to the corresponding value.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.IValueControl.IsReadWrite
member.summary: Determines whether the interactive user of the control can change the value.

remarks.para: The default value of this property must be equal to the corresponding value.

remarks.para: For reserved and pre-defined control page Ids, see .

member.summary: Requests that the interactive user of the control can set the value to null.

member.summary: Requests that the interactive user of the control can change the type of the value.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ComponentModel.IValueControl.RequestReadWrite
member.summary: Requests that the interactive user of the control can change the value.

This value isn't actually used.

member.summary:
The data type is a sequence.

Corresponds to the data type class and generic data class.

member.summary:
The data type is opaque.
Remarks:
Corresponds to the data type class and generic data class.

member.summary:
The data type is an enumeration.
Remarks:
Corresponds to the data type class and generic data class.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.DataTypeKind.Structured
member.summary:
The data type is structured.

Corresponds to the data type class and generic data class.

member.summary: The data type is a union.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.DataField.DataType
member.summary: The data type of the contents of the field.

remarks.para: If the data type is a null reference, or is incomplete, the data field is incomplete (the property equals to false).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.DataField.IsComplete
member.summary: Determines whether the data field is complete, i.e. the data type is filled in and is also complete.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.DataField.IsTerminable
member.summary: Determines whether the data field is terminable, i.e. can produce a finite generic data.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.DataField.IsLength
member.summary: Determines whether the field denotes a length of some sequence.
member.remarks: Length fields in can in some cases be auto-completed, or their value overriden, before encoding.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.DataField.IsOptional
member.summary: Determines whether the field may be omitted from the encoded data.
member.remarks: Whether or not the field is encoded may depend on other factors, such as the value of a switch field.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.DataField.IsSwitch
member.summary: Determines whether the field acts as a switch for some other field.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.DataType.FullName
member.summary: The full name of the data type.

remarks.para: The syntax and semantics of the full name are given by the data type system this data type belongs to. For example, in OPC UA Binary data type system, the full name is a string form of its , where the namespace is the target namespace of the dictionary that defines the data type.
The full name is meant to be unique if possible, but does not necessarily have to. Whether the full names are truly unique depends on the data type system, and its configuration.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.DataType.IsComplete
member.summary: Determines whether the data type is complete, i.e. all constituent data types are filled in.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.DataType.IsRecursive
member.summary: Determines whether the data type is recursive, i.e. contains any cycle.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.DataType.IsTerminable
member.summary: Determines whether the data type is terminable, i.e. can produce a finite generic data.

member.summary: Finds an enumeration member by its value.

member.returns: Returns an which has the value given by the parameter. When there is no such enumeration member, the function returns a null reference. When there is more than one match, the first matching enumeration member found is returned.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.SequenceDataType.ElementDataType
member.summary: The data type of the elements of the sequence.

remarks.para: If the element data type is a null reference, or is incomplete, the sequence data type is incomplete (the property equals to false).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.SequenceDataType.Int32Length
member.summary: How many elements the sequence has. Equals to -1 when unknown (e.g. dynamic). A 32-bit signed integer.
member.remarks: This member is exposed mainly for COM interoperability.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.SequenceDataType.IsFirstArrayDimension
member.summary: Determines whether the sequences represents the first dimension of an array.

remarks.para: When this property is true, this sequence data type and all its immediately following element sequence data types that have this property set to false define an array (single-dimensional if there is no such element data type, or multi-dimensional otherwise). On the contrary, with an element sequence data type that has this property set to true, an array of arrays (jagged array) is defined.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.SequenceDataType.Length
member.summary: How many elements the sequence has. Equals to -1 when unknown (e.g. dynamic).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.DataTypeModel.GenericData.DataType
member.summary: The associated data type of the generic data.

remarks.para: When the is returned from the server by the component (e.g. from read operations or by subscriptions), this property is always filled in (i.e. not null).

When the is passed in to the component for transfer to the server (e.g. to a write operation), it is optional. When not null, the component checks the value in against the data type given by this property, and issues an error if the value does not conform to the type. It is allowed for this property to be not null at some higher level, and be null at lower level, such as for an individual field of a structure.

When the data type is given and passed to the component, it is only used for the checks described above. It does not influence the actual encoding of the values, and the encoding process may further reject some input values as not conforming to the encoding.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Data.StatusInfo.Unknown
member.summary:
Unknown status.
Remarks:
The status may be unknown when it is not possible to connect to the source/target object. As such, depending on the application and interpretation, the unknown status can represent a problem that is more serious than the status.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Extensions.FileProviders.IFileInfoExtension.CreateStreamReader(Microsoft.Extensions.FileProviders.IFileInfo,System.Text.Encoding)
member.summary: Creates a with specified encoding that reads from an existing text file.
member.param: A file info that represents a file in the file provider.
The character encoding to use.
member.returns: Returns a new for reading from this file info.

remarks.para: This method is similar in purpose to , but is generalized for any kind of file info, not just files in the physical file system.

The object attempts to detect the encoding by looking at the first four bytes of the stream. It automatically recognizes UTF-8, little-endian Unicode, big-endian Unicode, little-endian UTF-32, and big-endian UTF-32 text if the file starts with the appropriate byte order marks. Otherwise, the user-provided encoding is used. See the method for more information.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Extensions.FileProviders.IFileInfoExtension.ReadAllText(Microsoft.Extensions.FileProviders.IFileInfo)

overloads.summary: Returns the contents of a text file in an abstract file provider as a .

member.param: A file info that represents a file in the file provider.
member.returns: containing the contents of the file.

remarks.para:
This method is similar to
FileSystem.ReadAllText Method for normal (operating system) files.
Note: This method allows you to read from a text file. The contents of the file are returned as a string.

The file encoding can be specified if the contents of the file are in an encoding such as ASCII or UTF-8. If you are reading from a file with extended characters, you need to specify the file encoding using the appropriate overload of this method.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Extensions.FileProviders.IWritableDirectoryContentsExtension.CreateSubdirectory(OpcLabs.BaseLib.Extensions.FileProviders.IWritableDirectoryContents,System.String)
member.summary: Creates a subdirectory or subdirectories on the specified path. The specified path can be relative to this instance of the .
member.param: The writable directory contents object that will perform the operation.
The path of the subdirectory to be created.
member.returns: Returns the writable directory contents for the subdirectory that has been created.

remarks.para: This method is similar in purpose to , but is generalized for any kind of writable directory contents, not just files in the physical file system.

Any and all directories specified in are created, unless some part of is invalid or the creation fails. The parameter specifies a directory path, not a file path. If the subdirectory already exists, this method does nothing.

For , , , and , relative paths are based on the directory itself; absolute paths are based on the root directory of the file provider. Notice the difference from , and , where relative paths are based on the directory where the file is located.

remarks.para: Do not use this method unless you are implementing . If you are consuming and want to delete an empty directory, use the method with a 'recursive' argument set to false.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Extensions.FileProviders.IWritableFileInfoExtension.MoveTo(OpcLabs.BaseLib.Extensions.FileProviders.IWritableFileInfo,System.String)
member.summary: Moves a specified file to a new location, providing the option to specify a new file name.
member.param: The writable file info object that will perform the operation.
The path to move the file to, which can specify a different file name.

remarks.para: This method is similar in purpose to , but is generalized for any kind of writable file info, not just files in the physical file system.
You can use this method to rename a file, keeping it in the same parent directory, too.
This method can be used with an absolute path pointing in .
This method does not overwrite the destination file if it already exists. For that purpose, call instead.
For , and , relative paths are based on the directory where the file is located; absolute paths are based on the root directory of the file provider.

Note: This method method opens a file, writes to it, and then closes it. Code that uses this method is simpler than code that uses a object with a . member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Extensions.FileProviders.IWritableDirectoryContents.MoveTo(System.String)
member.summary: Moves a directory and its contents to a new path.
member.param: The name and path to which to move this directory. The destination cannot be a directory with the identical name. It can be an existing directory to which you want to add this directory as a subdirectory.

remarks.para: This method is similar in purpose to , but is generalized for any kind of writable directory contents, not just files in the physical file system.

You can use this method to rename a directory, keeping it in the same parent directory, too. You need to specify an absolute path in this case (or a relative path that uses navigation above the root). It is recommended to use the method if your intent is renaming and not moving. The has additional checks that guarantee that renaming and not moving will occur.

For , , , and , relative paths are based on the directory itself; absolute paths are based on the root directory of the file provider. Notice the difference from , and , where relative paths are based on the directory where the file is located.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Extensions.FileProviders.IWritableFileInfo.MoveTo(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves a specified file to a new location, providing the options to specify a new file name and to overwrite the destination file if it already exists.
member.param: The path to move the file to, which can specify a different file name.
true to overwrite the destination file if it already exists; false otherwise.

remarks.para: This method is similar in purpose to , but is generalized for any kind of writable file info, not just files in the physical file system.

You can use this method to rename a file, keeping it in the same parent directory, too. It is recommended to use the method if your intent is renaming and not moving. The has additional checks that guarantee that renaming and not moving will occur.
This method can be used with an absolute path pointing in .
For , and , relative paths are based on the directory where the file is located; absolute paths are based on the root directory of the file provider.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Extensions.Internal.ObjectDescriptorExtension.CreateInstance(OpcLabs.BaseLib.ObjectDescriptor,System.Guid)
member.exception: An error has occurred during application execution.

remarks.para: Framework Design Guidelines: "AVOID defining extension methods on System.Object. VB users will not be able to call such methods on object references using the extension method syntax, because VB does not support calling such methods. In VB, declaring a reference as Object forces all method invocations on it to be late bound (the actual member called is determined at runtime), while bindings to extension methods are determined at compile-time (early bound).

member.name: T:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Graphs.Extensions.ITreeTraversableExtension
member.summary: Contains extension methods to the interface.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Graphs.Extensions.ITreeTraversableExtension.PreventRecursion``1(OpcLabs.BaseLib.Graphs.ITreeTraversable{``0})
member.summary: Creates a derived traversable that prevents recursion into nodes that have already been traversed.
member.typeparam: The type of objects to traverse.
member.param: The tree traversable for which the recursion will be prevented.
member.returns: Returns a tree traversable where nodes that have already been traversed are returned without their children being traversed again.

remarks.para: If a node is to be returned that has already been traversed, it is still returned; only its children are not traversed again. The result thus allows reconstruction of the original tree, if so required.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Graphs.Extensions.ITreeTraversableExtension.PreventRecursion``1(OpcLabs.BaseLib.Graphs.ITreeTraversable{``0},System.Collections.Generic.IEqualityComparer{``0})
member.summary: Creates a derived traversable that prevents recursion into nodes that have already been traversed, using the specified equality comparer for comparing traversed nodes.
member.typeparam: The type of objects to traverse.
member.param: The tree traversable for which the recursion will be prevented.
The equality comparer to be used for comparing traversed nodes.
member.returns: Returns a tree traversable where nodes that have already been traversed are returned without their children being traversed again.

remarks.para: If a node is to be returned that has already been traversed, it is still returned; only its children are not traversed again. The result thus allows reconstruction of the original tree, if so required.

member.summary: None.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Instrumentation.LogEntryType.Error
member.summary: An error. This indicates a significant problem the user should know about; usually a loss of functionality or data.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Instrumentation.LogEntryType.Warning
member.summary: A warning. This indicates a problem that is not immediately significant, but that may signify conditions that could cause future problems.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Instrumentation.LogEntryType.Information
member.summary: An information. This indicates a significant, successful operation.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Instrumentation.LogEntryType.SuccessAudit
member.summary: A success audit. Security: An indication that occurs when an audited access attempt is successful; for example, logging on successfully.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Instrumentation.LogEntryType.FailureAudit
member.summary: A failure audit. Security: An indication that occurs when an audited access attempt fails; for example, a failed attempt to open a file.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Internal.Background.ComSecurityIsGuaranteedInitialized
member.summary: Determines whether COM security is guaranteed to be initialized.

remarks.para: Returns true when we know positively that the COM security has been initialized either by us, or some other actor. It could be that it has not been initialized with the parameters specified, but it does not matter here. Also, returns true on platforms that do not support COM. Otherwise, returns false (meaning that the information cannot be determined).
For debugging.
When inside the Background value factory, you can determine the call stack that created the object as follows:

ol.li: In the call stack of the current thread, locate and select the nearest frame with the .CreateProtected.__ProtectedParameterizedStart|0 method.
The 'obj' local variable contains the instance. Expand it, and under "Raw View" (when Visual Studio debugger is used), locate the StackTrace private property.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.LiveBinding.PointBinderCore.DesignFastestUpdateRate
member.summary: Fastest update rate used when the design is made online.
member.remarks: When the design is made online, it can be much more demanding on computer resources, because each value update causes value changes that need to be reflected by the designer, regenerating code and making other changes in the environment. In order to maintain responsiveness, the update rate is limited.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.BaseLib.OperationModel.OperationException
member.summary: Exceptions arising from performing operations.

remarks.para: In general, you cannot safely prevent these exceptions from happening. Conditions external to your code can cause failures. For this reason, you should always expect that an operation can fail.

Operation exception always contains a (non-null) inner exception. This is because it is thrown as a wrapper exception by single-operation methods, but multiple-operation methods return the inner exception through their results, and therefore the inner exception is the one that actually determines the error cause.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Runtime.InteropServices.ComInstantiationParameters.OverrideDefaultSecurity
member.summary: Override the default activation security for machine remote activations.

remarks.para:
This property is used by following client implementations:
Native client: yes
NET API client: no
When set, a non-null COAUTHINFO will be specified in the COSERVERINFO.pAuthInfo member passed as the pServerInfo parameter to the CoCreateInstanceEx. See COSERVERINFO structure (objidl.h).
This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Runtime.InteropServices.ComInstantiationParameters.TurnOffActivationSecurity
member.summary: Indicates that activation security should be turned off when the COM object is created.

remarks.para:
This property is used by following client implementations:
Native client: yes
NET API client: no
In order to turn off the activation security, the property must also be set to true.
See Turning Off Activation Security. For this to work, the server must specify Everyone for Default Launch Permissions.
This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Runtime.InteropServices.ComManagement.AssureSecurityInitializationAndRunOnStaThread(System.Action{OpcLabs.BaseLib.OperationModel.Generic.ValueResult{System.Boolean}})
member.summary: Assures that COM security is initialized, and runs the specified action on an STA thread.
member.param: The action to be run on an STA thread after the COM security is initialized.

remarks.para: This method can be used in programs that were originally designed to run on an STA thread, but had to be switched to an MTA thread in order to prevent premature COM security initialization. The method assures the COM security initialization using the method, and then runs the specified on an STA thread. The current thread is used, if it already is an STA thread; otherwise, a dedicated thread is created for the execution, and its apartment state is set to STA. In both cases, the control returns to the caller after the has completed. The takes a single argument, which is the result of the COM security initialization, as returned by the method call.
The is executed even when the COM security initialization fails.

exception.para: A null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) is passed to a method that does not accept it as a valid argument.
This is a usage error, i.e. it will never occur (the exception will not be thrown) in a correctly written program. Your code should not catch this exception.

member.exception: An error has occurred during application execution.

member.summary: Allow the server to impersonate the client.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Runtime.InteropServices.ComSecurityParameters.EnsureDataIntegrity
member.summary: Verifies that none of the data transferred between client and server has been modified.

remarks.para: For KB5004442Manage changes for Windows DCOM Server Security Feature Bypass (CVE-2021-26414).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Runtime.InteropServices.ComSecurityParameters.TurnOffCallSecurity
member.summary: Sets the authentication level for COM object access to None.

remarks.para: This settings has effect only when is true.

This property is used by following client implementations:
Native client: yes
NET API client: yes
See Turning Off Call Security. For this to work, the server must also specify None for its authentication level.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Runtime.InteropServices.ComSecurityParameters.UseCustomSecurity
member.summary: Indicates that custom security settings should be used for COM object access.

remarks.para: When true, the COM security settings of the application are controlled by the application itself, and are not influenced by the settings specified in DCOM Configuration. Unless specified otherwise, access is allowed to everyone, authentication level is set to Connect and the impersonation level is set to Impersonate.

This property is used by following client implementations:
Native client: yes
NET API client: yes

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.CertificateGenerationParameters.AllowUserInteraction
member.summary: Determines whether the component can interact with the user when creating a certificate.
member.value: If set to false (the default), no dialogs will be displayed.

remarks.para: Setting this property to true has effect only when the current process is running in user interactive mode.
Following paragraphs apply only to certificates generated using the OPC Foundation .NET stack.

The actual user interaction controlled by this parameters is performed by a code in OPC UA Configuration Library. As such, it does not have the same visual appearance and behavior as user interface provided by the component itself. Specifically, the dialogs do not have timeouts associated with them. This means that the current activity can be blocked for extended periods of time, or even indefinitely.

The situations in which the user interaction controlled by this parameters happens are quite rare. Following dialogs or message boxes can appear when this parameter is set to true:
Any errors encountered while loading the SDK application configuration (this does not normally happen, because the SDK application configuration is pre-loaded by the component).
User confirmation required to update the application own certificate when the key size in the current certificate is less than the required minimum key size.
Only for applications that are not just OPC UA clients, but also OPC UA servers: User confirmation required to update the application own certificate when the server is configured to use a domain which does not appear in the current certificate.
User confirmation required to update the application own certificate when the current certificate does not specify the application URI.
This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.CertificateGenerationParameters.MaximumExpirationDate
member.summary: Maximum expiration date of the generated certificate.

remarks.para: Use this property is you want to limit the certificate validity by end absolute date in the future.

The resulting lifetime of the certificate is dictated by the earlier of dates implied by and . Since the default value of is relatively low, if you want to prevent the from being reduced by the , you may have increase the to a very large value.
The resulting certificate lifetime might be up to 1 month later than what is implied by , due to the limitations of the underlying certificate generation mechanism.

Use this property with caution. Setting an absolute maximum expiration date influences how the certificate is generated, but it also means that unless this date is changed, after some point in the future, it will not be possible to generate a valid certificate with this setting.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.CertificateGenerationParameters.MinimumKeySize
member.summary: Minimum key size of the generated certificate (in bits).

remarks.para: The underlying generation certificate mechanism will choose a key size that is greater or equal to . The default value of , which is zero, causes the certificate generation mechanism to choose the default key size.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.CertificateGenerationParameters.ValidityPeriodInMonths
member.summary: Validity period of the generated certificate. In months.

remarks.para: Use this property is you want to limit the certificate validity relatively to the generation date.
The resulting lifetime of the certificate is dictated by the earlier of dates implied by and .

member.name: T:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.Cryptography.MD5Managed
member.summary: MD5Managed: A HashAlgorithm implementation that acts as a thin wrapper around a C# translation of the MD5 reference implementation. member.summary: Same as . Returns the serial number of the PKI certificate as an array of bytes in little-endian order.
member.returns: The serial number of the PKI certificate as an array of bytes in little-endian order.

remarks.para: This method has been introduced as an alternative way to achieve the functionality of for some COM consumers (such as Microsoft C++ native COM support #import), where the automatically generated getter function for the property becomes GetSerialNumber, causing a conflict.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.Cryptography.PkiCertificates.PkiFileFormat
member.summary: File formats used in PKI.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.Cryptography.PkiCertificates.PkiFileFormat.None
member.summary: No PKI file format.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.Cryptography.PkiCertificates.PkiFileFormat.Authenticode
member.summary:
PKI file format with an Authenticode certificate.
Remarks: Corresponds to .
A variant of PKCS #7.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.Cryptography.PkiCertificates.PkiFileFormat.Cert
member.summary:
Same PKI file format as , but implies a different file extension.
Remarks:
Common file extensions: .cer.
Binary format.
Contains single certificate.
No private key.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.Cryptography.PkiCertificates.PkiFileFormat.Der
member.summary:
The DER (Distinguished Encoding Rules) file format for PKI. Same as , but implies a different file extension.
Remarks:
Common file extensions: .der.
Binary format.
Contains single certificate.
No private key.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.Cryptography.PkiCertificates.PkiFileFormat.Pem
member.summary:
The PEM (Privacy Enhanced Mail) file format for PKI.
Remarks:
Common file extensions: .ca-bundle, .cer, .crt, .key, .pem.
Text format, Base64 with headers&footers.
Contains single certificate, or more certificates in a path.
Optional private key.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.Cryptography.PkiCertificates.PkiFileFormat.Pfx
member.summary:
The PFX file format for PKI. Currently the same as , but implies a different file extension.
Remarks:
Corresponds to or .
Common file extensions: .pfx, .p12.
Binary format.
Contains all certificates in a path.
Can have private key.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.Cryptography.PkiCertificates.PkiFileFormat.Pkcs12
member.summary:
The PKCS #12 file format for PKI. Currently the same as , but implies a different file extension.
Remarks:
Corresponds to or .
Common file extensions: .pfx, .p12.
Binary format.
Contains all certificates in a path.
Can have private key.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.Cryptography.PkiCertificates.PkiFileFormat.Pkcs7
member.summary:
The PKCS #7 file format for PKI.
Remarks:
Corresponds to .
Common file extensions: .p7b, .p7c, .p7s.
Text format, Base64 with headers&footers.
No private key.
Contains certificates or CRLs.
Our file format name: PKCS7.

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.Cryptography.PkiCertificates.PkiFileFormat.SerializedCert
member.summary:
PKI file format with a single serialized certificate.
Remarks:
Corresponds to .

member.name: F:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.Cryptography.PkiCertificates.PkiFileFormat.SerializedStore
member.summary:
PKI file format with a serialized store.
Remarks:
Corresponds to .

remarks.para: This synchronization is different from what, for example, offers. It affects only the specific certificate security interaction, with the intent to be used to guard e.g. the memoization of it. Synchronizing on the interaction provider level would be too wide. Also, we can honor here the timeouts.
There is a hidden input to all , and that is a current time. For this reason, memoizing should not be used when the output can change with time.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.KeyManagement.Configuration.ManagedSecurityGroupParameters.MaximumRequestedKeyCount
member.summary: Maximum number of security keys requested from the security source.

remarks.para: In theory, we could request any number of keys in the valid range, even the highest value. Some security key sources, however, may not deal with it well, if they have not implemented the count limitation properly; issues like memory allocation failures can arise. This parameter allows to prevent such issues from the consuming side.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.KeyManagement.Configuration.ManagedSecurityGroupParameters.MaximumRequestedKeyCountDecimal
member.summary: Maximum number of security keys requested from the security source, expressed in Decimal type.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.KeyManagement.Configuration.ManagedSecurityGroupParameters.MaximumRequestedKeyCountDouble
member.summary: Maximum number of security keys requested from the security source, expressed in Double type.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.KeyManagement.Configuration.ManagedSecurityGroupParameters.MinimumDelayBetweenGetSecurityKeys
member.summary: Minimum delay between subsequent calls to the GetSecurityKeys method. In milliseconds.

remarks.para: This delay prevents unwanted, immediately repeated GetSecurityKeys requests in case that the security key source does not return enough future keys to satisfy even the time implied by .
There is, of course, an increased danger that when this minimum needs to be applied, the security keys provider will run out of available keys.
The only applies when fetching future keys.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.KeyManagement.Configuration.ManagedSecurityGroupParameters.MinimumFutureKeyReserveTime
member.summary: Minimum amount of time contained in a reserve of future security keys. In milliseconds.

remarks.para: Normally, <= .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.KeyManagement.Configuration.ManagedSecurityGroupParameters.MinimumPastKeyReserveTime
member.summary: Minimum amount of time contained in a reserve of past security keys. In milliseconds.

remarks.para: Normally, <= . This is inverted in comparison to future key reserve times, but it makes sense: The past key reserve grows with time, so we can request less, but eventually it will reach the minimum reserve time.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.KeyManagement.Configuration.ManagedSecurityGroupParameters.RefetchCurrentKeysFactorOfKeyLifetime
member.summary: A factor relative to key lifetime, determining a delay before a secure sender requests new current keys.

remarks.para: This parameter is only used by secure senders (typically, publishers).

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.KeyManagement.Configuration.ManagedSecurityGroupParameters.RequestedFutureKeyReserveTime
member.summary: Amount of reserve time for which future security keys will be requested. In milliseconds.

remarks.para: Normally, <= .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Security.KeyManagement.Configuration.ManagedSecurityGroupParameters.RequestedPastKeyReserveTime
member.summary: Amount of reserve time for which past security keys will be requested. In milliseconds.

remarks.para: Normally, <= . This is inverted in comparison to future key reserve times, but it makes sense: The past key reserve grows with time, so we can request less, but eventually it will reach the minimum reserve time.

remarks.para: Executes sequentially when equals to .
Always returns some result: If no selector result satisfies the predicate, returns result of a random selector.

In principle, there should be no exceptions thrown from the selectors. If it happens nevertheless, the selector is treated as if the predicate has failed for that selector. Exceptions in selectors are swallowed, unless all selectors throw an exception; in such case, the method throws a single or aggregate exception consisting of the exceptions thrown by the selectors.

remarks.para: For debugging.
When inside the asynchronous delegate, you can determine the call stack that called the method as follows:

ol.li: In the call stack of the current thread, locate and select the nearest frame with the System.Runtime.Messaging.StackBuilderSink.AsyncProcessMessage(...) method.
Expand the 'replySink' local variable, expand its AsyncState property. It contains the instance. Expand it and locate the StackTrace property.

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Widgets.NotifyingWidget.SynchronizedCallOrSend(System.Threading.SendOrPostCallback,System.Object)
member.remarks: This method is designed to prevent nested calls to . Example: Some delegate callback code is executed on thread A through WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext.Send (or maybe simply on an UI thread directly?), and this code calls WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext.Send again. If, by that time, other threads (B) have called WindowsFormsSynchronizationContext.Send on the same synchronization context, their delegate callback code will now (somewhat expectedly) be executed on thread A, and even before the actual delegate callback passed to the Send method. In some cases, this is undesirable and can cause serious problems, e.g. deadlocks because of the unexpected locking protocol violations. This methods detects the situation and calls the delegate directly, preventing callbacks from other threads being "injected" at this point.

remarks.para: This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: T:OpcLabs.BaseLib.Xml.Serialization.Mvp.XmlSerializerCache
member.summary: The XmlSerializerCache allows to work around the assembly leak problem in the ( LINK ) The cache will inspect if it contains any previously cached instances that are compatible with the parameters passed to the various overloads to the GetSerializer method before constructing a new XmlSerializer instance.
member.remarks: In contrast to the , the XmlSerializerCache requires a permission set that allows reflecting over private members.

member.returns: Returns true if this object descriptor is null; otherwise, returns false.
member.remarks: An object descriptor is considered empty when it has its initial scheme, the remaining parts of the URL string are empty, and both and are empty.

remarks.para: This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ObjectDescriptor.Location
member.summary: The object's location.
member.remarks: Corresponds to the host or machine name.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ObjectDescriptor.MachineName
member.summary: Name of the machine. Determines the computer on which the object is located. May be an empty string, in which case the object is assumed to exist on the local computer or at the computer specified for it by DCOM configuration.

remarks.para: Machine resources are named using the naming scheme of the network transport. By default, all UNC ("\\server" or "server") and DNS names ("domain.com", "example.microsoft.com", or "135.5.33.19") names are allowed.
There are maximum length limitations on the machine name.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ObjectDescriptor.ObjectId
member.summary: Contains the object ID, i.e. ProgID, {CLSID}, or ProgID/{CLSID}.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ObjectDescriptor.ProgId
member.summary: Contains ProgID of the object.

remarks.para: There are maximum length limitations on the ProgId.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ObjectDescriptor.ServerClass
member.summary: Contains {CLSID} (if given), or ProgID of the object.

remarks.para: There are maximum length limitations on the server class.
The and return different values if both the CLSID and ProgID are present.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ObjectDescriptor.ServerProgram
member.summary: Contains ProgID (if given), or {CLSID} of the object.

remarks.para: There are maximum length limitations on the server program.
The and return different values if both the CLSID and ProgID are present.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ObjectDescriptor.ShortUrl
member.summary: A short URL of the resource.

remarks.para: This property is null if the underlying string does not represent a valid URI.
This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ObjectDescriptor.ShortUrlString
member.summary: A short URL string of the resource.

remarks.para: The short string is formed by removing the CLSID part, if both the ProgID and the CLSID are present.
This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.remarks: A null reference denotes that a URI is not available.

remarks.para: This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.summary: A URL string of the resource.

remarks.para: A generic string is used instead of , because in some cases, the value may not represent a real URI.

member.name: T:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor
member.summary: Contains data defining a resource (mainly, its URL string).

remarks.para: Modifying properties other than or is only guaranteed to yield a correct result when a valid URL is already set in the ; further restrictions also apply.
An implicit conversion from a containing the URL of the resource exists. It is therefore common to specify -s as strings, relying on the implicit conversion.

member.summary: Converts a to a resource descriptor.
member.param: The string to be converted.
member.returns: For a non-null input, returns the resource descriptor with the given URL string. Returns null if the input is null.

remarks.para: A generic string is used instead of , because in some cases, the value may not represent a real URI.
This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: M:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.op_Implicit(System.Uri)~OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor
member.summary: Converts a to a resource descriptor.
member.param: The URI to be converted,
member.returns: For a non-null input, returns the resource descriptor with the given URI. Returns a resource descriptor with an empty URL string if the input is null.

remarks.para: This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.summary: Converts a string to a resource descriptor.
member.param: A URL string of the resource.
member.returns: Returns a resource descriptor with the specified network address (resource URL).

remarks.para: A generic string is used instead of , because in some cases, the value may not represent a real URI.
This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.returns: Returns a resource descriptor with the specified resource URL.

remarks.para: This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.Authority
member.summary: Holds an optional user-information part, terminated with "@" (e.g. username:password@); a hostname (e.g., domain name or IP address); and an optional port number, preceded by a colon ":".

remarks.para: This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.DescriptorString
member.summary: A string that represents the resource descriptor or its relevant parts.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.PathAndQuery
member.summary: Gets the concatenated Path and Query properties.

remarks.para: This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.SchemeAndAuthority
member.summary: Gets the Scheme and Authority properties separated by a colon (:) and double forward slash (//) as needed.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.UserInfo
member.summary: Gets the UserName and Password properties separated by a colon (:). Not normally used with OPC UA - see the documentation!

remarks.para: This property is normally not used with OPC UA. For username/password authentication in OPC UA, use the UAEndpointDescriptor.UserIdentity.UserNameTokenInfo property, and its sub-properties.
This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.UrlString
member.summary: A URL string of the resource.

remarks.para: A generic string is used instead of , because in some cases, the value may not represent a real URI.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.Fragment
member.summary: The fragment portion of the URI.
member.remarks: The Fragment property contains any text following a fragment marker (#) in the URI, including the marker itself. When setting the Fragment property, the fragment marker is added to its value.

remarks.para: This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.Host
member.summary: The Domain Name System (DNS) host name or IP address of a server.
member.remarks: The Host property contains the fully qualified DNS host name or IP address of the server.

remarks.para: This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.IsNull
member.summary: Determines whether the resource descriptor is null.
member.returns: Returns true if this resource descriptor is null; otherwise, returns false.
member.remarks: A resource descriptor is considered null when is empty.

remarks.para: This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.Password
member.summary: The password associated with the user that accesses the URI. Not normally used with OPC UA - see the documentation!

remarks.para: This property is normally not used with OPC UA. For username/password authentication in OPC UA, use the UAEndpointDescriptor.UserIdentity.UserNameTokenInfo property, and its sub-properties.
This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.Path
member.summary: The path to the resource referenced by the URI.

remarks.para: The Path property contains the path information that the server uses to resolve requests for information.
The path information does not include the scheme, host name, or query portion of the URI. The Path property always returns at least a slash (/).
There are maximum length limitations on the URI path.
This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.Port
member.summary: The port number of the URI.
member.remarks: The port number defines the protocol port for contacting the server referenced in the URI. If a port is not specified as part of the URI, the property returns the value -1 to indicate that the server uses the default value for the protocol.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.Prefix
member.summary: A scheme name followed by a colon. An empty string if there is no scheme.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.Query
member.summary: The query information included in the URI.

remarks.para: The property contains any query information included in the URI. Query information is separated from the path information by a question mark (?) and continues to the end of the URI. The query information returned includes the leading question mark.
The query information is escaped according to RFC 2396.
This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.Scheme
member.summary: The scheme name of the URI.

member.name: P:OpcLabs.BaseLib.ResourceDescriptor.Url

member.remarks: A null reference denotes that a URI is not available.

remarks.para: This method or property does not throw any exceptions, aside from execution exceptions such as or .

It seems that others who have designed an interface with this name and purpose have chosen to make it a generic interface. For our initial purposes (serialization testing), a generic interface would only complicate the usage. If needed, a generic interface can later be *added*, keeping the non-generic interface as well.

See also:
https://github.com/sillsdev/machine/blob/master/Collections/IValueEquatable.cs
http://daisy-trac.cvsdude.com/urakawa-sdk/browser/trunk/csharp/core/IValueEquatable.cs?rev=2735&order=name
http://urakawa.sourceforge.net/sdk/csharpdoc/html/386ea43d-5277-f851-c5d2-693015973250.htm

member.returns: A indicating the result.
member.remarks: We intentionally allow null to be passed in, in order to match the behavior of .

member.name: T:JetBrains.Annotations.ContractAnnotationAttribute
member.summary: Describes dependency between method input and output
member.syntax:
Function Definition Table syntax:
FDT ::= FDTRow [;FDTRow]*
FDTRow ::= Input => Output | Output <= Input
Input ::= ParameterName: Value [, Input]*
Output ::= [ParameterName: Value]* {halt|stop|void|nothing|Value}
Value ::= true | false | null | notnull | canbenull
If method has single input parameter, it's name could be omitted.
Using halt (or void/nothing, which is the same) for method output means that the method doesn't return normally.
canbenull annotation is only applicable for output parameters.
You can use multiple [ContractAnnotation] for each FDT row, or use single attribute with rows separated by semicolon.

item.code: [ContractAnnotation("halt <= condition: false")] public void Assert(bool condition, string text) // regular assertion method
[ContractAnnotation("s:null => true")] public bool IsNullOrEmpty(string s) // string.IsNullOrEmpty()
[ContractAnnotation("s:null=>false; =>true,result:notnull; =>false, result:null")] public bool TryParse(string s, out Person result)
